headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Trump Clashes with Social Conservatives on Abortion; White House, Biden Campaign Holding Separate All-staff Calls; Trump Campaign Tight-lipped amid Growing VP Speculation. Aired 12:30-1p ET

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- being here. Now, you can call me Dana the entire time.(LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Tell me this current status --

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- of what the debate is right now and whether or not you think as somebody who believes that this should be a national issue, not a states issue, where it will end up.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So what you are saying is that you're not just coming at this from the stance where you're completely anti-abortion?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You're coming at it from the stance politically, strategically --

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- from the idea that if a woman is living in a state with no exemptions, really strict bans --

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- that it would be better for them to have a national ban that at least has some exceptions, and abortion is not till 20 weeks.

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Well, the federal minimum standard that we have been trying to get accepted by the party and used as an important thing to run on, has been a minimum standard. So, a baby at seven months in California has the same rights as a baby at seven months in another state. So that's a minimum standard. States can go further than that, but they can at least -- they would at least establish that place.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I see, got it.

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: That contrast makes sense to most people, not people who are in the rabid pro-choice side and the excited pro-life base, but it is a consensus and that's where we are in this nation post-Dobbs. That's what I think were required to do. Focus on saving those lives, as many as we can, and serving women.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: How about the process? Because I have heard complaints from people in your camp about the fact that the people in the Trump campaign have been taking those who want to keep a national ban in the GOP platform off the platform committee.

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Well, we are closed out, so I can't tell you what I think is going on. It's very, very different I call to know. We've been lobbying for what we want. Nobody wants to be closed out. It is the first time it has happened in anybody's memory. It is the prerogative of the president -- former president to do this as he wants. I don't agree with how it is happening and I wouldn't agree with changing things up and causing a problem where there shouldn't be. But, that is the reality of what we are dealing with.What we don't want to communicate to our voters and to voters in the middle is that there is no job that can be done in Washington to address this on a national level, on a minimum standard level. That would be a bad communication and it would be demoralized.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So, you are shut out of the process?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Just to be clear, because I hope I didn't confuse our viewers with my question to you. Your stance is a national abortion ban, you call it limits?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I mean, I of course am pro-life. I believe that life begins at conception. Also, I know that we are at a place in our country to build consensus. So the national limit, 15 weeks with exceptions is such a moderate -- modest --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And that's what should be in the platform?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: And that would be a great extension of that fundamental language. That fundamental language is, a 14th Amendment justification for any legislation, that should be retained.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So, you would be happy if there was a support for a national ban at 15 weeks with exceptions for the health of the mother, rape and incest?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yes. As long as that language stayed intact, that appeals to the 14th Amendment.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So, I checked in with the Trump campaign, Chris LaCivita to be specific, before this interview to get a sense of what they're saying about this notion that you're shut out and here is what he said. It is the natural -- it is the natural way of conventions that the leading campaign ensures it has supporters in those roles. This is Donald Trump's convention, not Marjorie's.

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: He is exactly right and he gets to do what he wants.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And --

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Of course, we don't --we don't like this. I am not the head of the party. We -- the pro-life movement is not a function of the Republican Party. It is a one cause 14th Amendment press. It is a human rights movement of our day. We are not Republicans first and pro-lifers next. So, it is all -- what Republicans do will determine what we do.Now, let me tell you what we are going to do and it is still a contrast. We are still in those battlegrounds. It is just a plea to -- from the outside to the inside, to retain that language and the heart and soul of the of the pro-life movement which has served the Republican Party for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And you're going to be still out there trying to get people to vote?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Are you also saying that you're worried that this will dampen enthusiasm?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: How big of an enthusiasm problem might you have?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, we hear reports of all sorts of people saying they are not going to vote, will have profile like people out there in the pro-life movement. I would think that would be a mistake. Clearly, the contrast is still very advantageous for Trump. We cannot have a law that would wipe out every single pro-life protection in the country. But I do think it will be demoralizing and we see evidence of that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: One last question --

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- and then we got to go. Would you like any protections for IVF in the platform?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: I think there is a lot of good conversation about this. I think that more fertility treatments are called for. The American public poll after poll shows they don't like the development of a lot of embryos just to be destroyed. So that is the conversation we are having about --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That you (ph) want to be part of the platform or stay out?

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: I think it would be fine to communicate what the Republican Party is for in the platform.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK. We are going to have you back to talk more about that. Thank you so much for coming on.

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: DANNENFELSER
utterances.sentences: Thanks.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right now, the president and vice president are having lunch together at the White House. Also happening now, Biden Chief of Staff , Jeffrey Zients, is holding an all-staff call with White House staff and Biden's Campaign Chair Jen O'Malley Dillon and Campaign Manager Julie Chavez Rodriguez are holding their own call with campaign staff.So Zolan, Jeff and Jackie are back with us. So, that is all happening as we speak. So as soon as we get the reporting on that, we will bring it to you. In the meantime, I just want to return to the story that MJ brought us and give a little bit more of the details of that story about the president's thinking. In Tuesday's private conversation, Biden was also chastened as he blamed himself and not his staff for the terrible debate last week. He said, I have done way too much foreign policy, this person said. Biden said that the back-to-back trips to France and Italy, and the jet lag and exhaustion that had caused was detrimental for the debate but wanted to put the debate in the rear-view mirror. And so that's the question. Is there a rearview mirror?

utterances.speaker: JACKIE KUCINICH, WASHINGTON BUREAU CHIEF, THE BOSTON GLOBE
utterances.sentences: Right now, no, because they haven't dealt with --there has been so many explanations as to why that happened. Was he sick? Was he tired? What -- but what was it? And so, I think because there has been -- there hadn't -- there wasn't a clear answer coming out of that debate and there has been the reluctance to deal with the fact that the president is aging from the campaign and the White House for that matter, that just -- it just leaves more questions.And the fact that he did not reportedly reach out to anybody after that debate, he didn't talk to Congressional leaders. He didn't talk to allies, all of that kind of created a stew that they haven't quite figured out how to serve. I think we can go with that. (LAUGH)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Let's go with that, yeah.ZOLAN KANNO-YOUNGS, WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT, THE NEW YORK TIMES: And we have reporting as well that after that sort of lag in reaching out to key allies that the president himself did reach out to a key ally and expressed that he may not be able to salvage this (inaudible) unless over the coming days, he can turn the tide here and sort of convinced the public, as well as Democrats that the debate was a one- off and that he is up for the job. It just reinforces the idea that the next -- the actions by the White House and by the president specifically in the coming days are so crucial to the future of his campaign now. And I will say, I'm also talking not just to Democrats outside the White House, but those inside the campaign that are also watching this meeting with the chief of staff today, watching his events to see sort of what the future is for this campaign at this time. The anxiety also runs within the administration right now.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And again, we should just emphasize that everybody I've talked to frames it with one clear goal, keeping Donald Trump out of the White House and what is the best way to do that.

utterances.speaker: JEFF ZELENY, CNN CHIEF NATIONAL AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: And unity is something that Democrats will be searching for. That is one of the topics to be discussed by optics and actual agenda at the governor's meeting tonight. But you mentioned that campaign call going on, urging staffers to stay focused, that is their biggest worry of all. This has taken their eye off the ball on Donald Trump and the contest.That is why, someone said to me this morning, it took Biden a long time to decide whether and when to run. He is known to be a very deliberate/slow decision-maker. They say he does not likely have that much time in this scenario, A, because the convention is coming up, but B, just the amount of lost time here. Again, the silent campaign has been the Trump campaign because they know this is beneficial to them. KANNO-YOUNGS: And let's also remember, while all this is going on, one still needs to keep governing too. This is a pivotal time with two wars going on and the NATO Summit in Washington, D.C., that has now taken on even more important when it comes to domestic politics as well with that coming just next week.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump and his team are focusing on the busy sprint to the Republican National Convention. There is a lot of speculation about who will be his VP pick, but Trump is being uncharacteristically quiet on what could be a defining moment in this race. CNN's Kristen Holmes has been covering the former president and is covering the so-called veepstakes. What are you hearing?

utterances.speaker: KRISTEN HOLMES, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, I want to say that in the last hour, I said Donald Trump has been laying low and not doing any interviews. And apparently, the campaign said he did a Virginia local radio show, so I want to correct that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK.HOLMES But this is uncharacteristically --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That's low-ish.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: -- it is low profile. BASH

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: And when I said are you arguing that he is laying low, there was no response on that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Meaning they are asking you what is happening in Biden world (ph)?

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: Exactly. One of the things, obviously --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: -- you've talked about before --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: -- when they start coming for information --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HOLMES
utterances.sentences: -- they need to figure out their plan of action. Now when it comes to VP, we are still told that the top contenders remain the three, North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, Marco Rubio, as well as J.D. Vance. Trump has a rally in Miami that they are planning in --on Tuesday, and I'm told point-blank over and over again, do not read too much into that. It does not mean anything. Obviously, Marco Rubio's hometown there, but they are having a big rally on that day as well. A lot of speculation building, but whether or not he ultimately does it, that's going to be his decision and anyone around him will tell you, they just don't know.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I think that's the one thing we do know.(LAUGH)
